lines.text: [first lines]
Zorro... Zorro... Zorro...
If this be the governor, then angels have turned politicians.
What's she want here?
For breakfast, a priest to bury her father. For lunch, Zorro's head on a pikestaff.
She does, eh? Thinks she can give me orders? I'll get my hands on her and govern her with a lash.
Bravo. There's no more bracing treat than beating women. Of course, it will cost you your head.
Oh, what?
The queen is her aunt. And the queen hates having her nieces flogged by the soldiery.
That horse killed a man.
All the more reason for a woman to master it. Bring the beast to me.
No, I beg of you, don't break your neck. I have important matters to discuss with you. Your marriage...
Marriage? To you, I presume? If you don't mind, I'll break my neck.
Well met, father.
God's blessing on the meeting.
Father, the day we've prayed and planned for is at hand. Never again will the peóns be enslaved for taxes.
Our God be praised.
The commandante's rule is over. We have a most wise, a most lovely, and a most beautifully spoiled governor.
You said you'd give anything to him who hangs Zorro, remember? Now, will you give half of Santa Cruz to me... by marriage?
I marry a sweating, grease-brain brute like you? No, never.
[last lines]
Amen.
My father, dying, left me all he had; power, land, money... and a debt of vengeance. I'll pay with all I have... even my life!
Zorro, Zorro, Zorro... You chatter like parlor maids chasing a mouse. I'll hang him within a month.
But this is treason!
No, lady. This is common sense. You would betray me tomorrow as you betrayed him today.
There's an outlaw in these woods. He's lead a native uprising. He must be killed and by whatever means come best at hand.
[the Commandante lashes his whip at Don Diego]
Mercy! What have I done?
Nothing. That's just to keep my hand in incase I have to lash the life out of some fool who would betray me.
I'm sorry, but I have no use for men who smell of perfume.
